Question_1.Context: A dynamic bidirectional communication system exists among the gut, its microbiome, and the central nervous system (CNS). This system may influence brain health and various brain-related diseases, especially in the realms of neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative conditions.
Question_1.Question: What is often referred to as a dynamic bidirectional communication system among the gut, its microbiome, and the CNS?
Question_1.Source: A new perspective suggests that a dynamic bidirectional communication system, often referred to as the microbiome-gut-brain axis, exists among the gut, its microbiome, and the central nervous system (CNS).

Question_2.Context: Metabolites or extracellular vesicles derived from microbes in the gut can traverse barriers, gaining access to the systemic circulation and potentially influencing the CNS.
Question_2.Question: Which substances derived from gut microbes are capable of traversing barriers and potentially influencing the CNS?
Question_2.Source: Metabolites or extracellular vesicles derived from microbes in the gut have the capacity to traverse the intestinal epithelial barrier or blood–brain barrier, gaining access to the systemic circulation.

Question_3.Context: Alterations in the composition of the gut microbiome have been associated with various neurodevelopmental, neurodegenerative, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
Question_3.Question: What has been associated with a range of neurodevelopmental, neurodegenerative, and neuropsychiatric disorders?
Question_3.B: Alterations in the composition of the gut microbiome
Question_3.Source: Alterations in the composition of the gut microbiome have been associated with a range of neurodevelopmental [1], neurodegenerative [2, 3], and neuropsychiatric disorders [4].

Question_4.Context: Gut microbes intricately regulate neural development and function by modulating the production of various neurotransmitters.
Question_4.Question: What role do gut microbes play in neural development and function?
Question_4.A: They supply essential vitamins for neural growth
Question_4.B: They provide physical support to neural structures
Question_4.C: They modulate the production of various neurotransmitters
Question_4.D: They form the myelin sheath around neurons
Question_4.Source: Moreover, within the context of the gut-brain axis, the gut microbes have been observed to intricately regulate neural development and function by modulating the production of various neurotransmitters [6].

Question_5.Context: Gut microbes play a pivotal role in the transformation and metabolism of dietary and host-derived molecules, producing a diverse array of metabolites with both local and systemic effects.
Question_5.Question: What is the role of gut microbes in the transformation and metabolism of molecules?
Question_5.B: Generating a diverse array of metabolites with systemic effects
Question_5.D: Synthesizing hormones for the gut only
Question_5.Source: Gut microbes play a pivotal role in transformation and metabolism of dietary and host-derived molecules, giving rise to a diverse array of metabolites with both local and systemic effects [7].

Question_6.Context: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) generated by gut microbes play a role in regulating the function of peripheral immune cells as well as neural and microglial function.
Question_6.Question: What role do short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) generated by gut microbes play?
Question_6.A: They regulate the function of peripheral immune cells and neural function
Question_6.B: They are solely responsible for digestion
Question_6.C: They act as neurotransmitters within the CNS
Question_6.D: They form the structural components of cell membranes
Question_6.Source: Furthermore, SCFAs generated by gut microbes play a role in regulating the function of peripheral immune cells as well as neural and microglial function [12, 13].

Question_7.Context: Bacterial metabolites regulate signaling and neurotrophic factors, which are crucial for maintaining neural and synaptic growth, survival, and differentiation.
Question_7.Question: What do bacterial metabolites regulate that is crucial for neural and synaptic growth, survival, and differentiation?
Question_7.Source: Additionally, the bacterial metabolites regulate signaling and neurotrophic factors including brain-derived neutrotrophic factor (BDNF), nerve growth factor (NGF), and glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) [15].

Question_8.Context: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) generated by intestinal bacteria are suggested to play a significant role in cross-species and cross-organ communication.
Question_8.Question: What significant role are extracellular vesicles (EVs) generated by intestinal bacteria suggested to play?
Question_8.Source: EVs generated by intestinal bacteria have been suggested as a possible significant controller of cross-species and cross-organ communication, serving a crucial role in the normal functioning of the body and the brain’s physiological dysfunction [21].

Question_9.Context: Gut microbe-derived extracellular vesicles (GMEVs) can diffuse into the bloodstream and initiate distinct signaling pathways within the brain.
Question_9.Question: What can gut microbe-derived extracellular vesicles (GMEVs) do once they diffuse into the bloodstream?
Question_9.A: They can initiate distinct signaling pathways within the brain
Question_9.B: They can directly increase nutrient absorption in the gut
Question_9.C: They can enhance the oxygen-carrying capacity of red blood cells
Question_9.D: They can form a protective barrier against toxins
Question_9.Source: The gut microbe-derived extracellular vesicles (GMEVs) have the capacity to be released into the gut lumen and diffuse into the bloodstream, initiating distinct signaling pathways within the brain via the systemic circulation [22].

Question_10.Context: Gut microbe-derived extracellular vesicles (GMEVs) can exert diverse effects on various types of brain cells due to the abundant and diverse array of proteins and small ribonucleic acids they contain.
Question_10.Question: Why can gut microbe-derived extracellular vesicles (GMEVs) exert diverse effects on various types of brain cells?
Question_10.A: Due to the presence of digestive enzymes
Question_10.B: Because of the high concentration of lipids
Question_10.C: Owing to the abundant and diverse array of proteins and small ribonucleic acids
Question_10.D: As a result of their ability to transport oxygen
Question_10.Source: These EVs can exert diverse effects on various types of brain cells (e.g., neurons, astrocytes, and microglia) due to the abundant and diverse array of proteins and small ribonucleic acids [23, 24].
